reviews.text: A taste of old Europe that is accessible for non royalty. Attended an event here that was fabulous. I think that's all real gold highlighting the various rooms. Great view from up on the hill. Definitely go for a night time event. I didn't see it the normal tourist way.

The biggest attraction in Bratislava. Recently improved a lot with opening of museum and back lawn. Due to location at a higher place, beautiful view of city,s important landmarks especially river Danube

I have to say my whole experience travelling to Bratislava wasn't so nice, especially the Castle. It was heavily restored, everything was so new, lost all the purpose as a historical attraction at least for a traveller like me. Next thing is the things inside the castle itself, most of them are replicas, printings and paintings were mostly copied version. Even the real ones are rom other countries like Russia. Most of the rooms were very empty, even the souvenirs shops occupied many of the rooms, and then the modern art exhibition on the top floor. Last but not least, our only hope of understanding a bit more of the castle and history of Slovakia from videos in the castle itself are all in Slovak language and Russian.. not even English. Seems like the administration of the castle don't really care about people from other countries.. no audio guide is fine, but at least make the important information of video in English version. The view from the castle is fine, but not worth the visit as a whole. Especially if u have been to castle in Prague or Vienna. I have to say most of the tourist attractions in Bratislava are not ready for tourists yet..

A wonderful work in progress. The outside has been rebuilt impressively well however the interior is quite sparse and has a way to go. The exhibitions were informative and I enjoyed learning about the history of Bratislava and the castle. Great viewpoints from the top and around the grounds, great photo opportunities.
Great value. Some furnished rooms with period appropriate furniture would be nice. Otherwise a really good experience even though 100's and 100's of steps. Go up the crown tower well worth the climb.
Interesting and free. It is situated near the river, in the old part of the city. Quite a few things to see around and lots of cafes and restaurants nearby.
Great experience, will be returning again.
Very good

The museum has 5 floors of art, where the lower are focused on traditional art and the top modern and installation art. Be aware that you'll have to pay €1 to take photos of the art. I really enjoyed the modern art which I thought was fantastic, especially the hallway of books. Just brilliant.
Great art
Moznost videt svet z jine perspektivy

Very small museum, cool knowledgeable guides that seem to master a lot of the countrie's historic, traditional and mythological stories. In an hour you can see most part of it. There is a little shop outside of the museum where you can buy some artifacts that are also available elsewhere at lesser price.
I like this place but I would love it if it had enough traditional and local object. I think it doesn't represent enough the national heritage

I loved visiting this museum. I wish I could've taken pictures. Nevertheless, our tour guide, William Dayo, was very well versed in each of the exhibits. It was really nice to have someone with us who gave us in depth information on what we were viewing. It gave us a deeper understanding and appreciation for each of the artifacts.
It was nice. The museum has a lot to offer in cultural history and I was happy to see them opened on a Sunday.

This museum continues the tradition of equating Western African culture and history mainly with masks (sarcasm). It could almost be interchangeable with the museum's in Dakar and Bamako except they both have a second floor dedicated to textiles. 

Granted, the masks are interesting and high quality, but they are completely decontextualized with cryptic captions an little explanation tying anything together.

There is one table showing the evolution of money that was nice. 

It's one of the few times I wished there was a museum gift shop with some books. 

Weirdly they don't allow photography either, as if history should be hidden. 

Avoid the restaurant out back it is way overpriced and there are better maquis around.

This place is great! Most of the exhibits have explanation in English as well as Slovak.
The woolly mammoth is the top!
Never thought I would see such a thing...I also need to mention a bison and a giraffe...
Proper cool...
Been there only once at the Tibet Himalaya exhibition and I liked it. A pleasant surprise.

The museum exhibits a vast range of specimens from various segments of natural history, mainly focused on presentation of the diversity of living and non-living nature in Slovakia. The museum also hosts a variety of temporary exhibitions (check the program on official website).

The museum had interesting exhibits but they could have been better organized and presented. Many tags were written only in Slovak and that made it difficult to follow the exhibitions. You should totally visit if you have a lot of time but i would prefer something else if on a tight schedule

Really interesting museum for all nature lovers. Some taxidermy pieces were really done well, and I love the backgrounds which were made like their real habitat. Whole exhibition is a chronological story from the begining of the life on planet Earth to life we know today. I have so much photos which I could share, but it is best for you to go there and experience it yourself. :)

A place where you can spend just under an hour and have a lovely look at what life used to be like in the past. Very beautiful items on exhibition. From transport to old road signs and much more. There is a room to get a little coffee if you need.

Owners/workers were very kind and sweet.

Slovak Technical Museum – Museum of Transport – documents the development of railway and road transport of Slovakia. Cars with or without engine produced before the World War II. Bicycles, personal vehicles and lorries from the interwar period. Vehicles from the 60s and 70s of the 20th century. All this plus some temporary exhibitions will bring you closer to understand how Slovak transportation has changed in time. The exposures are situated in former stores, built in the characteristic industrial style of the early 20th century. You will travel in time thanks to this visit!
Fairly interesting. No comments or maps about what you are looking at or you should go. Shame, really.

Absolutely brilliant! The place is for all ages. My 9 year old had a blast! Its not a big museum but filled with so much history, from cars to trains to motorcycles and bicycles. There is an area outdoors where you can see the different type of trains and see how they were built. There are some clothing references from back in the days even reconstructions of rooms. There is no touchy feely side for the kids to play around but I'm sure they will be more than excited about the visit as there is something for everyone here.
Awesome vehicles,free on the first Sunday of the month..

The oldest and the most beautiful church in Bratislava full of beautiful decorations, colourful windows with wonderful mosaics. The statues decorating the interior show the rich catholic history of this town and its importance in Hungarian kingdom in the past. 
Must see point in Bratislava.
Historic and sacral place, unfortunately compromised by near highway. Great organ music. Some sections are restricted - probably as result of keeping tourist buzz controlled.

A wonderful church that was the site of many historical events including the coronations of Hungarian monarchs. It is next to the modern main road but that has not affected the buildings charm or looks with it being easily accessible from the old town. It is almost always on the route to the castle so well worth visiting on the way.

The largest and finest, as well as one of the oldest churches in Bratislava in which Queen Maria Theresa was crowned. It is the second most popular tourist location in Bratislava. Its 85 m high spire dominates Old Town’s skyline. Make sure you visit its underground crypt with catacombs. I loved this beautiful old church.
A 13th century Gothic - style, catholic cathedral with chapels and navies used for coronation--full of beautiful decorations, near the highway.

Very beautiful and interesting church. Never seen anything like it in my life. Worth seeing if you're into architecture. No photo will do it justice. The facade colours are something you don't usually see. If you're ever in Bratislava definitely visit.

I promised myself that if I'm going to marry, I'll marry here in this church even though I'm not christian. (Actually I have no religion.) When I visited there, the church was closed and I almost cried out of sadness. From the outside part, the church looks amazingly pretty. For the inside part, it's even more beautiful. The name 'blue church' is the perfect description of this church because it's a church, and its color is (beautiful light) blue. As Bratislava is a small city, you have plenty of time to look at this church thoroughly.

There is story behind the blue facade and the church could do a lot more to promote it. Try to visit when it is actually open. Best time is our before mass. On Saturday your chances of running into a wedding are extremely high :-) The school next to the church is actually just as architectonically interesting.

We enjoy the walk from old town to this famous blue church! 
Unfortunately we didn't know the opening time for visit so we missed the chance to go inside. Dont missed it when you in Bratislava old town! 

Here is the time table opening : 
Monday - Saturday: 6.50am -7.35am & 17.30pm - 19.00pm 
Sunday: 7.30am - 12 noon & 17.30pm - 19.00pm

When we got there, the church was locked. So, we couldn't get in it. From the outside is stunningly beautiful and different from any other church you've seen. Just next to it there is a school with the same style. The school has its own sun clock.
A good place to have an afternoon coffee and roam around after school.  My favorite is the food truck selling pommes frites.

The Old Town Hall on Bonn's marketplace was built 1737-1780 in the style of the Rococo by the electoral court architect Michael Leveilly. The three-storey building has a mansard roof with dormers. It is listed as an architectural monument. In the Square about a day in a week there's a Market...
Good place to have some coffee or buy cheap grocery
Very nice building

Absolutely gorgeous town hall located on the market off Bonn. On the market you can buy some great food and when it is sunny have a nice cool drink on the terraces. It is easily reachable on foot and bus, tram and metro stops aren't far away.
Szép hely.
Škoda že nie je nejak viac prístupná verejnosti
Historický kus mesta. Nezničme si ho
One of the most interesting building in Bratislava. Unfortunatelly it is really hard to get in and owerall shape of the building needs some renovations.
I mean what can you say. It's an upside down pyramid built during the communist period and you either love it or hate it. Well worth a look if just to see what you think yourself!

We have been here for a New Year's concert of Bratislava Hot Serenaders and it was awesome. The ambiente is very socialist style but absolutely worth to see. It was for the first time that I was visiting a concert which was broadcasted live in a radio. Great experience.
It's a beautiful and well-preserved building. I recommend guided tours. You will get to interesting places in the interior and hear about history.
Didn’t go in, but is an impressive structure nonetheless. Truly unique
An excellent medieval fountain totally ruined by adding another round marble rim. Cannot imagine what kind of barbaric psycho could have approved it.

Oldest standing fountain in the city, it was ordered by Maximilian II, Holy Roman Emperor after a fire in 1563. Major reconstruction in the mid-18th century, outer pool added in 2006. The fountain features in local legends. It is a Slovak National Cultural Monument.

Great place to spend evening in Bratislava! Situated in the center of night activities, it's a happening place. Small streets with restaurants, cafeteria and ice cream parlours around. Great crowd. It also has historical importance.
Maximilianova Fountain. A statue of Maximilian II, King of Hungary, who built a public water supply here in 1572.

Simply amazing fountain witnessing alots of history  events and kings coronations.
It is located in the main town square.near the cafes.

Amazing experience. The food servings were big and the prices were decent. Sadly, they didn't really have a variety of local beers. One Slovak and the rest were German and Czech. However the atmosphere was nice. We ordered the wiener schnitzel and the chicken paprikas with bread dumplings which was absolutely my ultimate favorite. Will definitely visit again to get the bacon and goat cheese potato gnocchi.

Food is delicious, service is fast and professional, waiters are very polite. Prices are also not too high. We ordered backed fish, warm salad with turkey and Halooshki - Slovakian local dish. Everything was perfect! Really enjoyed a food and place. The only thing we didn't like was a bathroom, which is downstairs outside the restaurant. If you are coming with old people, would not recommend.

Perfection!! 
Come early or book in advance as this little restaurant fills up fast!
The onion soup was great! Fabulous taste and a little different to what we were expecting! The chicken vegetable broth was a simple tasty dish. 
Schnitzel was cooked perfectly with great potatoes and a small accompanying salad. We didn’t know what to expect of the pork chop in potato but it was simply delicious. The salad that comes with this balances out the meat. 
The staff were helpful, funny and friendly and very accommodating. 
We certainly will be back on our next visit to Bratislava.
Good food, nice dessert, quality drinks. We enjoyed here very much and highly appreciated the service. Highly recommended.

Excellent food and great service.  Lot of photos of early 1900’s.  The tables are close together but not right on top of another.  They had a duck special that was very good. I also had a chicken wrapped in pancake in sauce that was magically delicious.  
If I lived in Slovakia, they would get all of my money and I would weight 600 pounds.
